title: Up and running in minutes with Tailwind CSS and Alpine.js
description: Finding the time to work on side projects is tough, and the last thing you want to do is spend that time just getting your project to build. I'll show you how to leverage Parcel Bundler to get up and running in just a few minutes!

title: Launch: Front End Columbus Website
description: Designed, developed and launched the Front End Columbus website to provide a place for our community to connect with others, learn about meetings, and find/post local jobs.

title: A simple case for chatbot websites.
description: I found the idea of chatbots very exciting when the trend started a few years ago, to the point that I tried to build a startup around chatbot based food delivery (it didn‚Äôt go well). The allure to me was the potential to simplify the web. Chatbots allow you to break down complex websites into a decision tree of actions, rather than a scavenger hunt of links.

title: The Art of Validating Quickly
description: You‚Äôve refined cards, drawn sketches and created designs, but now you need a way to get your product in-front of real users. Without user feedback, how do you know if you‚Äôre on the right track?

title: Need a blog? Use GitHub as your CMS.
description: Why install Wordpress, Drupal or Ghost when you can use the markdown editor and pull request functionality of GitHub as the backend for your next blog?

title: CodeMash Conference: Design & Research Fundamentals for Developers
description: Presented a 4-hour conference workshop teaching the basics of UX design and research. Participants went through the UX process of discovery, design and usability testing.

title: The Importance of Full-Stack UX
description: As a frontend developer, its hard to avoid the necessity of knowing how backend systems work. Heck, you‚Äôll probably even be required to gasp write backend code on occasion. This is because frontend and backend developers often work hand in hand, and collaboration is fundamental to getting work done. So then why do we have such a strong separation between frontend development and the other parts of UX, such as design and research? Researchers, developers and designers often work together, but we rarely expect a developer to know anything about design or research. This is where full-stack UX comes in.

title: Getting Started with Django & Windows the Easy way
description: It used to be that developing in Python on Windows required a bunch of setup (installing Python, pip, setting up your PATH) and managing virtual environments. The days of this are over though with the latest update to Microsoft‚Äôs Visual Studio Code.

title: Senior UX Developer @ Insight Digital Innovation
description: Promotion from Staff UX Developer to Senior UX Developer.

description: Front-end developer and consultant at Cardinal Solutions. Responsible for front-end development, design, mentorship and communicating with clients.

title: Code & Beer: Print Stylesheets
description: Presented on techniques for developing print-friendly websites.

title: Front End Columbus: Print Stylesheets
description: Presented on techniques for developing print-friendly websites.

title: Code & Beer: Quickly Deploying .NET Core Applications on Digital Ocean with Dokku
description: Live demonstration of deploying a .NET Core & PostgrSQL application using Docker, Dokku and Digital Ocean.

title: ProZ.com Translators Day: Native Language Verification
description: Gave a live presentation on ProZ.com's Native Language Verification during their digital Translators Day event.

title: Product Launch: GiveYaw
description: Launched a low-friction tool for creating social media giveaways. Built with Vue and serverless.

title: Product Launch: MetaShort
description: Launched a one of a kind tool for social media marketers that enabled the customization of any link's meta tags. Built with PHP.

title: Web Developer @ ProZ.com
description: Worked as a fully remote full-stack web developer. Was responsible for all stages of feature development (concept, design, development, advertising, community engagement).

title: Termination of MetaShort.co Service
description: I am sad to announce that I will be shutting down the MetaShort service, effective immediately. MetaShort has been a wonderful project to work on, and it has been amazing seeing the number of people that found value in the product. Unfortunately the project has‚Ä¶

title: My experience going from idea to #3 on ProductHunt in under a month
description: On September 14th I created a folder called ‚Äúfinish me‚Äù on my desktop.This was the start of another silly idea that was going to distract me from the idea I was already working on (and grow into the #3 product on ProductHunt less than a month later).

title: The fight for your rental deposit
description: I‚Äôve jumped between apartments quite a bit over the past 7 years. My first time renting I was naive, I didn‚Äôt take pictures when moving in and I expected that if left the place in a fairly good condition I would get my deposit back. Many apartments (and a couple of lawyers) later, and I‚Äôve wised up to the fact that you have to fight for your rental deposit.

title: Web Applications Developer @ Fisher College of Business (OSU)
description: PHP and front-end developer working on custom Drupal solutions.

title: Graduated from Ohio University
description: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science

title: Musashi University, Tokyo
description: Completed a 4 month language exchange program in Tokyo, Japan.

title: Sclask Release
description: Web app for recording scores for office games. Records scores across multiple users and game types and provides predicitions for matches. Created in .NET Core and Vue, deployed via Dokku on Digital Ocean.

title: MeetTheDev Open Source Release
description: LinkedIn meets GitHub's profile timeline. An open-source template to create easily maintainable developer portfolios.

title: Westerville Web: It's okay to be bad
description: What if you stopped worrying about technology, design, and scalability and instead shipped your side-projects? Whether you‚Äôre a developer or not, everyone has ideas for the next big thing. Learn how to stop adding to your idea graveyard by not sweating the small stuff and instead using the tools you know to build and release products (even if they are a bit rough around the edges).
